title: 103_hr5049
content:
The Act titled "George Washington Boyhood Home Commemorative Coin Act of 1994" specifies the coin specifications. The Act "George Washington Boyhood Home Commemorative Coin Act of 1994" authorizes the issuance of 500,000 one-dollar silver coins with specific weight, diameter, and composition. The coins feature a design of George Washington's profile and his boyhood home, the "Ferry Farm", with inscriptions of the coin's value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The coins issued under the "George Washington Boyhood Home Commemorative Coin Act of 1994" feature inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". These coins are legal tender and considered numismatic items under the Act. The Secretary must obtain silver for the coins from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Minerals Stock Piling Act. The design for the coins will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single mint facility during the period of January 1, 1996, to December 31, 1996. The coins authorized under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, a surcharge of $12 per coin, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Prepaid orders will be accepted at a discount. All sales will include the surcharge. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS.

No procurement laws apply to goods and services for this Act, except for equal employment opportunity laws.

SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES.

Surcharges from coin sales go to George Washington Boyhood Home Foundation for restoration.

SEC. 9. AUDITS. The Comptroller General of the United States has the right to audit the George Washington Boyhood Home Foundation's expenditures. Financial assurances are also required. SEC. 10 of the Act ensures that minting and issuing coins will not cost the government. Payment for coins must be made in full, with satisfactory security or guarantees.
